        y1 - Y-coordinate of the first point
        x2 - X-coordinate of the second point

      • ellipse

        public void ellipse(float a,
                    float b,
                    float c,
                    float d)
        Draws a dashed ellipse. Uses the same signature for a, b, c, d as Processing's native implementation, and is sensible to ellipseMode() status. BEWARE! Dashed ellipses are expensive to compute, use with caution ;)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        c -
        d -

      • arc

        public void arc(float a,
                float b,
                float c,
                float d,
                float start,
                float stop)
        Draws a dashed arc. Uses the same signature for a, b, c, d, start, stop, as Processing's native implementation, and is sensible to ellipseMode() status. BEWARE! Dashed arcs are expensive to compute, use with caution ;)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        c -
        d -
        start -
        stop -

      • arc

        public void arc(float a,
                float b,
                float c,
                float d,
                float start,
                float stop,
                int mode)
        Draws a dashed arc. Uses the same signature for a, b, c, d, start, stop, mode as Processing's native implementation, and is sensible to ellipseMode() status. BEWARE! Dashed arcs are expensive to compute, use with caution ;)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        c -
        d -
        start -
        stop -
        mode -

      • arcPolar

        public void arcPolar(float a,
                     float b,
                     float c,
                     float d,
                     float start,
                     float stop)
        Draws a dashed arc from polar angles. As opposed to Processing's native implementation, which uses start and stop as the parameter along the arc, this method uses start and stop as the polar angles that define the boundaries of the arc. This is not consistent with Processing's implementation, but just feels right geometrically... ;)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        c -
        d -
        start -
        stop -

      • arcPolar

        public void arcPolar(float a,
                     float b,
                     float c,
                     float d,
                     float start,
                     float stop,
                     int mode)
        Draws a dashed arc from polar angles. As opposed to Processing's native implementation, which uses start and stop as the parameter along the arc, this method uses start and stop as the polar angles that define the boundaries of the arc. This is not consistent with Processing's implementation, but just feels right geometrically... ;)
        Parameters:
        a -
        b -
        c -
        d -
        start -
        stop -
        mode -
